MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters. This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn. Silent compiler warning. */ if (0 == strcmp (key, "name")) { if ((size > 0) && (size <= MAXNAMESIZE)) { char *answerstring; answerstring = malloc (MAXANSWERSIZE); if (! answerstring) return MHD_NO; snprintf (answerstring, MAXANSWERSIZE, GREETINGPAGE, data); con_info->answerstring = answerstring; } else con_info->answerstring = NULL; return MHD_NO; } return MHD_YES; } ``` Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function iterate_post: #define MAXNAMESIZE 20 ... #define MAXANSWERSIZE 512 ... #define GREETINGPAGE "

Welcome, %s!

" Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze: ```c snprintf (answerstring, MAXANSWERSIZE, GREETINGPAGE, data); ``` Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
scenario: The call snprintf(answerstring, MAXANSWERSIZE, GREETINGPAGE, data) uses the %s format with 'data' which is not guaranteed to be NUL-terminated. Although size is checked to be <= MAXNAMESIZE, that only bounds the available bytes, not that a terminator exists. snprintf reads the source string until a NUL byte, so if 'data' contains exactly 'size' bytes without a terminating '\0' (or the terminator lies beyond the provided buffer), snprintf will read beyond the bounds of the object pointed to by 'data'.
